awd_abstract_narration:
The main topics of this research program are mathematical models for soap films spanning a closed wire and soap bubbles. By the least action principle, the surface area of a soap film or a soap bubble will minimize among all films spanning the wire or among all bubbles including a fixed volume. The physical characterization of such surfaces says that the soap film and the soap bubble are respectively critical points of area or area subtracting enclosed volume. Mathematically, a soap film spanning a wire is called a minimal surface, and a soap bubble is called a surface of constant mean curvature (abbreviated as CMC). These two types of surfaces already caught interests by physicists and mathematicians in 1760s, and have been extensively-studied topics which also inspired the advances of many other subjects in mathematics and science. One general theory for proving the existence of such geometric objects, called the "min-max theory", has had striking recent successes, and will be the major object of study in this research program.  

More specifically, the PI will conduct research on the min-max theory and its applications for CMC surfaces and minimal surfaces with free boundary. In the first subject, the PI intends to prove topological bounds for the min-max CMC surfaces by Heegaard genus in a given three manifold, as well as to prove the existence of multiple CMC surfaces for a given mean curvature. The PI also plans to establish the min-max theory for constructing surfaces with mean curvature prescribed by an arbitrary smooth function, generalizing that of the CMC surfaces where the curvature functions are constants. In the second subject, the PI will investigate the compactness property, properness property, and Morse index upper bounds of the free boundary min-max minimal surfaces obtained by the PI with collaborators before; as applications, the PI plans to study minimal surfaces in singular or non-compact spaces by approximations using the free boundary solutions. The PI will finish a program on constructing min-max minimal disks with free boundary using the theory of harmonic maps.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project consists of several geometric variational problems pertaining to prescribing mean curvature problems for surfaces. The objects of interests are the mathematical models of soap films spanning a closed wire and soap bubbles. By the least action principle, the surface area of a soap film or a soap bubble will minimize among all films spanning the wire or among all bubbles including a fixed volume. These variational principles imply that the soap film and the soap bubble are respectively critical points of area or area subtracting enclosed volume. A surface is called a minimal surface if it locally minimizes area, and is called a constant mean curvature (CMC) surface if it locally minimizes area among volume preserving variations. These two types of surfaces already caught interests by physicists and mathematicians in 1760s, and have been extensively-studied topics which also advanced many other subjects in mathematics and science. During the reward period, the PI obtained several significant results on the existence and regularity of such surfaces. The main results can be divided into five groups. 

(1) The PI solved the famous Multiplicity One Conjecture in minimal hypersurfaces theory. In particular, the celebrated Algmren-Pitts-Scheon-Simon min-max theory, when applied to the volume spectrum introduced by Gromov, Guth, Marques-Neves, provides a sequence of closed minimal hypersurfaces counted with integer multiplicity. By our work, in a generic scenario, all aforementioned minimal hypersurfaces appear with multiplicity one, and hence the sequence forms a list of distinct solutions for the existence problem of closed minimal hypersurfaces. This work, when combined with earlier work of Marques-Neves on characterizations of Morse index, forms a complete Morse theory for the area functional.

(2) With Antoine Song, the PI discovered a surprising anti-ergodic phenomenon for closed minimal hypersurfaces. In particular, we proved that generically there always exist a sequence of unstable closed minimal hypersurfaces with arbitrarily large area and Morse index which accumulate around a stable minimal hypersurface. Such a phenomenon is usually called scarring in spectrum theory, and is not expected to exist in hyperbolic spaces, as compared with the famous Quantum Ergodicity Conjecture by Rudnick-Sarnak. Our work reveals the deep complexity of minimal hypersurface system.   

(3) With Da Rong Cheng, the PI made substantial progress on the existence problem of closed CMC surfaces with prescribed mean curvature and controlled topology. It has been conjectured that on a three dimensional sphere with positive curvature, there exist CMC two dimensional spheres of any prescribed mean curvature. We solved this conjecture by proving the existence of branched immersed CMC spheres. 

(4) With Jonathan Zhu, the PI continued our investigation on the min-max theory for prescribing mean curvature (PMC) hypersurfaces. In particular, we established a complete regularity theory for min-max PMC hypersurfaces for smooth generic metrics. This work played an important role in the PI's solution of the Multiplicity One Conjecture. With Jonathan Zhu, the PI also established a two-dimensional CMC min-max theory.  In particular, on any closed surface, we proved the existence of a closed balanced network of any prescribed constant geodesic curvature, hence partially answered a question of Arnold-Novikov.

(5) The PI continued the investigation on minimal hypersurfaces theory in compact manifolds with boundary. In compact space with boundary, the least energy principle also imposes certain boundary condition on the soap films, which says that the boundary of the soap film is perpendicular to the boundary of the ambient space. This is usually called the free boundary condition. A few years ago, the PI and collaborators proved the existence and regularity of minimal hypersurfaces with free boundary. In this project period, the PI and collaborators further proved general Morse upper bounds estimates, generic denseness results, and the corresponding Multiplicity One Conjecture. We also applied these tools to construct minimal hypersurfaces in certain singular spaces.
